title: 108_s1527
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that Lyme disease is a common bacterial infection transmitted by tick bites. Early detection is crucial as it can cause serious health issues if left untreated, affecting various organs and systems. Lyme disease accounts for 90 percent of all vector-borne infections in the US, but ticks also spread other disorders like ehrlichiosis and babesiosis. Tick-borne diseases have been reported in 49 states, with 90 percent of cases in 10 states. The actual number of cases is estimated to be 10 times higher than reported. The poor surveillance of Lyme disease results in cases being approximately 10 times higher than reported, making treatment more difficult due to the persistence of symptoms in many patients without reliable testing. Establishment of a Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee. Establishment of the Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee to advise on interagency coordination, collaboration with other organizations, and responses to constituency groups regarding efforts to address tick-borne disorders. Membership includes appointed members. The Secretary of Health and Human Services appoints voting members to the Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee from various member groups including the scientific community, tick-borne disorder voluntary organizations, health care providers, patient representatives, and state and local health departments. The Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee consists of appointed members representing various groups, with equal representation from each group. Ex officio members are also included. The Committee is co-chaired by the Assistant Secretary of Health and a public co-chairperson chosen by members, serving a 2-year term with voting rights. All members serve 4-year terms, and vacancies are filled as needed. The Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee fills vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment, with members serving until successors take office. Meetings are held at least twice a year, with agenda items added at the request of members. Reports are required annually by the Secretary. The Secretary is required to submit annual reports to Congress on activities under the Act, detailing progress in developing diagnostic tools and promoting awareness and education on Lyme disease and tick-borne disorders. $250,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004 and 2005 for Committee expenses. The Committee is authorized to receive funds for expenses and per diem costs in accordance with the Federal Advisory Committee Act, with the exception that no voting member can be a permanent salaried employee. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION FOR RESEARCH FUNDING. $10,000,000 authorized annually for research on Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders, prevention efforts included. SEC. 4. GOALS. The Senate recommends the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders, in consultation with relevant agencies. The Senate recommends the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders, including goals for developing diagnostic tests, surveillance, reporting, and prevention strategies. The Senate recommends a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases, including prevention and control of various diseases such as Masters' disease, ehrlichiosis, babesiosis, and others.
